address_registration.title: Address Registration (住民登録)
steps: Visit your local ward office (区役所, kuyakusho) or city hall within 14 days of moving
Bring your residence card, passport, and My Number card if you have one
Complete the 'Change of Address' form (転入届, ten'nyū todoke)
Submit the form at the registration counter
Receive your new residence certificate (住民票, jūminhyō)
address_registration.tip: Morning visits (9-11 AM) are typically faster. The process usually takes 15-30 minutes.
address_registration.cultural_context: Address registration is mandatory in Japan and connects you to local services like healthcare and voting.

bank_account.title: Opening a Bank Account (銀行口座開設)
steps: Choose a bank (major banks: MUFG, Mizuho, SMBC, or Japan Post Bank)
Visit a branch with required documents
Fill out the account opening application form
Set up your personal seal (hanko) or signature
Make an initial deposit (usually ¥1,000 minimum)
Receive your cash card and bankbook within 1-2 weeks
bank_account.tip: Bring a Japanese speaker if possible. Some banks have English-speaking staff at major branches.
bank_account.cultural_context: Japanese banks are very security-conscious. Having a local address registration is essential.

phone_contract.title: Mobile Phone Contract (携帯電話契約)
steps: Choose a carrier (NTT Docomo, au, SoftBank, or Rakuten Mobile)
Visit a store or apply online
Bring required identification documents
Choose your plan and phone model
Set up payment method (bank account or credit card)
Complete identity verification process
Receive your phone and SIM card
documents: Bank account details or credit card
phone_contract.tip: Consider budget carriers like UQ Mobile or Y!mobile for cheaper options. Some stores have English support.
phone_contract.cultural_context: Japanese carriers often require local bank accounts and have strict identity verification.

health_insurance.title: National Health Insurance (国民健康保険)
steps: Visit your local ward office within 14 days of address registration
Bring your residence card and passport
Fill out the health insurance application form
Pay the enrollment fee (varies by income)
Receive your health insurance card
Keep the card with you for medical visits
health_insurance.tip: Insurance covers 70% of medical costs. Always bring your card to medical appointments.
health_insurance.cultural_context: Health insurance is mandatory for all residents. It provides access to Japan's excellent healthcare system.

my_number.title: My Number Card (マイナンバーカード)
steps: Apply online at the My Number portal or at city hall
Submit required photos and documents
Wait for notification (usually 1-2 months)
Visit city hall to collect your card
Set up your PIN numbers (2 different PINs)
Activate digital certificate if needed
my_number.tip: The card serves as official ID and enables online government services. Very useful for taxes and applications.
my_number.cultural_context: My Number is Japan's social security number system, used for taxes, benefits, and government services.

residence_tax.title: Residence Tax (住民税)
steps: Tax is automatically calculated based on previous year's income
Receive tax notification in June
Choose payment method: lump sum or quarterly installments
Pay at convenience stores, banks, or set up automatic deduction
Keep payment receipts for your records
residence_tax.tip: First-year residents often don't pay residence tax. Set aside money monthly for the following year.
residence_tax.cultural_context: Residence tax funds local services like schools, roads, and community programs.
